awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Vertical gradients in Southern Ocean Radiocarbon across the major climate transitions of the last 30,000 years
awd_abstract_narration:
The Southern Ocean holds disproportionate influence in setting atmospheric CO2 variability and carbon storage in the deep ocean because it is a region featuring both upwelling and deep-water formation.  Consequently, considerable effort has been devoted to understanding the Southern Ocean conditions and processes that ultimately led to lower atmospheric CO2 during the last ice age. Radiocarbon is in principle the most diagnostic tracer for ocean/atmosphere carbon cycling over this time period. However, the existing body of radiocarbon data for the Southern Ocean is still limited temporally and spatially, while also suffering from some essential uncertainties that preclude firm conclusions about carbon cycling during the last ice age. This project involves a coordinated program of radiocarbon measurements in three distinct archives of Southern Ocean oceanographic change that span the last 30,000 years. These archives, including both marine sediment sequences and deep-sea coral samples, are located so as to capture the surface, intermediate and deep-water carbon cycle response to climate forcing. The objective of this program is to extend existing radiocarbon measurements while also directly resolving some of the principal uncertainties that currently limit the application of existing radiocarbon observations. The program will serve as a natural platform for engagement of underrepresented students to STEM disciplines and will include undergraduate and masters-level students recruited from local community colleges and state universities.

More specifically, the project includes i.) planktonic-benthic foraminiferal radiocarbon age measurements in a newly acquired sediment sequence off Mozambique (IODP Site U1477) that features exceptionally high resolution; the bottom water at this location is recently ventilated water subducted just south of the Subtropical Convergence, and, therefore, the benthic foraminiferal radiocarbon variability monitors that of the sub-Antarctic surface ocean; ii.) U-series/radiocarbon age pairs in a set of deep-sea coral samples collected from intermediate water depths off Tasmania; the radiocarbon variability expressed in this series of samples is intended as a direct comparison to that of the Mozambique foraminiferal sequence; iii.) extension of existing (but not yet definitive) planktonic-benthic foraminiferal age depth pairs in abyssal South Atlantic sedimentary sequences; the benthic foraminiferal radiocarbon variability at these sites should reflect the deep branch of the Meridional Overturning Circulation (MOC). The intention is to provide new observations that, both on their own and by unlocking the potential of existing measurements, will serve as direct tests of models of the relationship between climate forcing and carbon cycling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Radiocarbon is a uniquely powerful tracer of ocean carbon cycling and deep ocean ventilation that, among other insights, can determine when ocean interior water masses were last in contact with the atmosphere. However, reconstruction of the past distribution of radiocarbon throughout the ocean --a prominent means for assessing how ocean circulation changed over ice ages--depends on the availability of suitable archives. The most common approach to infer the radiocarbon distribution of the past deep ocean is to measure the difference between radiocarbon ages of co-registered surface- and deep-dwelling microfossils (planktonic and benthic foraminifera)  extracted from marine sediment cores. The success of this approach depends on the ability to relate planktonic foraminiferal radiocarbon content to that of the contemporaneous atmosphere—the so called reservoir age.  This is especially important in high latitudes such as the Southern Ocean, where deep waters are both formed and upwelled to communicate with the atmosphere. Yet it has been notoriously difficult to obtain continuous and reliable reservoir ages in the high latitude regions over thousands of years because of the highly dynamic sedimentation regimes.

For this project we capitalized on the unique aspects of an ultra high deposition rate sedimentary sequence in the Mozambique Channel (IODP Site U1477) to help better constrain the surface ocean reservoir age of higher latitude Southern Ocean sequences over the last 30 ka. The bottom waters of this site (430 meters water depth) originate directly from sinking surface ocean water in the northern subantarctic region, where upper ocean ventilation occurs. Thus, at this site, the benthic foraminiferal radiocarbon serves as a monitor of subantarctic surface ocean radiocarbon; and consequently benthic-planktonic radiocarbon age differences at this site should at all times yield the latitudinal gradient between subtropical surface ocean reservoir age and subantarctic radiocarbon age. 

A suite of 32 radiocarbon dates in IODP Site U1477, measured via accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS), exhibited surprisingly little variability in the benthic-planktonic foraminiferal age difference throughout the last 30 ka. These results were completely consistent with the radiocarbon content of U/Th dated fossil deep sea coral recovered from shallow subantarctic sea floor (off Tasmania), measured by co-P.I. at Columbia University.  The immediate inference from these combined data is that there was little variability in subantarctic surface ocean radiocarbon reservoir age over the transition from ice age to modern conditions. Our results stand in contrast to previous inferences of substantial increase of subantarctic reservoir age during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM).

Our results carry significant implications for new and existing records of deep Southern Ocean radiocarbon distribution. As part of this project, we generated a new benthic-planktonic foraminiferal radiocarbon record spanning the last 30 ka from two companion sediment cores collected from the deep Cape Basin (water depths of 4600 meters). This record, when combined with the surface radiocarbon reservoir age determinations, can be used to quantify the accumulation of old (radiocarbon-depleted) carbon in the deepest Southern Ocean water masses. The results join existing records in suggesting an increase of old carbon at depth during the height of the LGM, but differ from previous inferences in suggesting more modern ocean-like radiocarbon content in the deep Southern Ocean both before and after the LGM. Furthermore, these results demand a reconsideration of previous inferences of substantial increase in the radiocarbon age of mid-depth (water depths ~3800 meters) Southern Ocean, because these prior inferences depend on the assumption of a substantial increase of subantarctic reservoir age. In general, the results of this project will provide essential constraints for models of deep ocean ventilation across the last ice age transition.

Finally, one practical benefit of the radiocarbon results from this project is that they provide a highly-resolved chronology of ocean changes at the subtropical and subantarctic Southern Hemisphere sites that were investigated—a chronology that can be applied to a full suite of ocean “proxy” tracers for past temperature, salinity, nutrients and pH.

Broader Impacts:

This project provided the primary training and support for an SIO PhD student who belongs to a severely underrepresented group in geosciences (first generation, female, Hispanic). This project promoted the development of both laboratory and mentorship skills: the PhD student interacted with P.I.s at different career stages and, in turn, successfully engaged three undergraduate interns, all of whom are also underrepresented minority (URM) students. Thus, this project provided a successful platform for broadening participation on multiple levels.
